title: Emmanuelle Charpentier
summary: Emmanuelle Marie Charpentier (born 11 December 1968[2]) is a French professor and researcher in microbiology, genetics, and biochemistry.[1] Since 2015, she has been a Director at the Max Planck Institute for Infection Biology in Berlin. In 2018, she founded an independent research institute, the Max Planck Unit for the Science of Pathogens.[3] In 2020, Charpentier and American biochemist Jennifer Doudna of the University of California, Berkeley, were awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry "for the development of a method for genome editing" (through CRISPR). This was the first science Nobel ever won by two women alone.[4][5][6]
